segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: call is closed. We have a quorum. Please rise for today's invocation, led by the gentleman from Valencia, representative Miraba.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: Father, we just praise you and we thank you for getting everybody back safely today. And we bless you for the weather this weekend. Even though it's cold, we need the moisture here in New Mexico, and we thank you for that. Father, I just ask that your spirit

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: felt in this chamber and throughout this whole

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: Father, I ask that your will be done, that we are focused on what we are advancing your kingdom and not our own agenda. And Father, I just ask for, and I speak unity,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: for doing what's best for the people of the state of New Mexico. And I ask this in Jesus' name.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: General Lady from Burley, Representative Serinana, with the Pledge of Allegiance.

segments.speaker: UNKNOWN
segments.text: Before which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: from Sandobalt, Representative Hernandez, with the pledge to the New Mexico flag. Folks, folks, please remain standing. I'd like to offer a moment of silence for Alex Pretty, who was killed over the weekend in Minnesota. Please rise.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_04
segments.text: Speaker, I move we go to that order of business announcements and miscellaneous business.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: no objections? It is so ordered.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: you, members, for indulging. Moment of silence, I just been a heavy weekend for all of us. I know

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: a time of such political dysfunction

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: the threats of political violence against members of this House sometimes, but also members of the public, as in the case of

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: the responsibility we each hold within our legislative roles, within as members of this House and this legislature. As I've said over and over again, I have nothing but respect for each and every single one of you, regardless of political and ideological differences. Violence is never the answer.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: hope that we continue to move in that spirit over the next few weeks. I know that we can. I've seen us do

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: many times. So, again, thank you for indulging. Moment of silence. And

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: our journey over the next 20-plus days.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: of course, may God bless our country as she continues to heal

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: We have the gentlelady from Doñana with some introductions.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_06
segments.text: you, Mr. Speaker. Today on the rostrum, I've got some guests. We've got Tyler Overberger. He is the chair of the Messiah Valley Day in Santa Fe. If you'd like to stand. We've got Kevin Merhedge, board chair for the Greater Las Cruces Chamber of Commerce. And lastly, I'd like to introduce Debbie Moore. She is the president and CEO of the Greater Las Cruces Chamber of Commerce. And today we celebrate her extraordinary 40-year career working with the Chamber of Commerce, including her. Her impactful service with the Greater Las Cruces Chamber of Commerce, defined by dedication, leadership, and lasting influence. Debbie has been a cornerstone not only in the Las Cruces, but within the chambers in Albuquerque, Hobbes, and Rio Rancho, helping shape their missions and strengthening their reach across New Mexico. Beginning with her first legislative session in 1990, I don't know if you were born yet, Mr. Speaker, in 1990. Debbie went on to work with six governors, providing community, deep institutional knowledge, and the steady, trusted voice for the region's business community. For more than 25 years, she has tirelessly advocated for businesses, large and small, and leaves a legacy of service that will be felt long after she is her well-earned retirement. And so, Mr. Speaker, I'd like to especially acknowledge her today.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: Welcome to the House and thank you, Debbie, for all of your years of service.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: know you started when you were in daycare doing all that good economic development work. I've had the honor to convene with Debbie. I think it was a couple years ago you hosted us for a business roundtable with

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: Gallegos and several other members of this House, and very appreciative of that time.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: think we might have been talking cannabis. I don't remember, but it was good. It was a good conversation. We were talking cannabis, not over cannabis or doing cannabis, just talking about it. Talking about it. Be very clear. Welcome and thank you and congratulations on your retirement. I hope you have incredible plans ready to go.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_06
segments.text: Thank you, Mr. Speaker. And we also have people in the gallery from the chamber, if you would acknowledge them. As well, and from the Messiah Day in Santa Fe Committee.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: gentlelady, we have in the gallery, please rise as I call your names to be recognized. We've got four guests from the New Mexico Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research: Andrea Kiskaden, Senior Business Manager, Brittany Vander Wolf, Communications and Outreach Manager, Cynthia Airy, Program Coordinator, and Dustin Allen, IT Project Manager. Welcome to the House.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: I'm sorry if I butchered some of your names. My apologies.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_06
segments.text: you, Mr. Speaker. And also on your desk, if you'll notice that there are business holders that also they brought up as gifts for legislators today, I wanted to say thank you for those and acknowledge that they were also here. And, you know, there's

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_06
segments.text: of people. Here within the Doniana community, and I just wanted to thank them for making that trip. We're not so used to the snow, so coming up and bearing the hard weather. And I know that they were tough soldiers all weekend and still made it to every reception possible. So I appreciate that, and welcome to the House. Thank you, Mr. Speaker.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: Welcome, welcome to the House. Thank you for being here.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: Gentlelady from Burnley, your representative Sernana.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: you, Mr. Speaker, and good morning, everyone. I am proud to sponsor EPSCoR today in the House of Representatives. And EPSCORE,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: today on the rostrum by Dr. Ganesh Balakrishman.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: New Mexico EPSCoR. He holds a PhD in optical science and engineering from the University of New Mexico and conducts photonic research related to semiconductors. Thank you. Welcome to the House.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: Speaker, I also have Dr. Selena

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: who is the Associate Director of EPSCoR. She holds a PhD in curriculum and instruction from Texas Tech University and is a proud graduate of Las Cruces High School.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: to the House. Bulldogs. Is that right?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: Mr. Speaker, I want to tell you a little bit about what EPSCoR does.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: it's the established program to stimulate competitive research and is a program started by the National Science Foundation to help higher ed, government, and businesses work together in science and technology projects. And currently, EPSCoR is working to solve three big problems in New Mexico. First, they're working to ensure that all New Mexico institutions can participate in research and innovation through the Research Infrastructure Optimization of New Mexico with the Rio New Mexico project.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: those institutions are the University of New Mexico, New Mexico State, New Mexico Tech, and Navaco Tech.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: second problem, and this affects everyone, how to monitor forests and rivers so we can better protect them after disasters like wildfires.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: the third big problem EPSCoR is looking at is how to strengthen advancing manufacturing through research and workforce development. And we need that for everything we're

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: how New Mexico EPSCoR stands out, its impact is to make, it makes a huge impact on our state. First, it has invested more than $100 million in research. It has secured $12 million in additional research funding since 2021. They are training and supporting more than 2,000 researchers. They are investing more than $7 million in research equipment and tools.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: are establishing 32 new faculty in high-impact science and engineering disciplines. And they are connecting all of New Mexico's higher education institutions to New Mexico's national research. Laboratories. In their program, the main goals are to support students who want to study science and engineering, yay, and to help improve science and engineering in ways that last in New Mexico, and to encourage research in important topics for New Mexico. So, that is EPSCoR, and they have given you this beautiful beaker. So, you can measure how much water you drink because we have to keep drinking that water.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: Only water, that's right. As someone in our other committee talked about. So, thank you for being here, and thank you for honoring EPSCoR today.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: Thank you. Thank you, EBSCORE, for being here today.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: thank you for explaining what EPSCoR was, because I legit was going to ask, and somebody please tell me what it does. So, that was very helpful. Thank you, gentlelady.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: from Doña Ana, and also from

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: and Catron and Valencia. No, I'm sorry, hold

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: from Doñana, Sierra and Socorro, Rup Samdao.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_10
segments.text: Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I am standing today to celebrate Ski New Mexico Day. Anna is walking around with your pass. You do have to sign for because this is

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_10
segments.text: very, very nice little gift for us and our families. And boy, we sure take advantage of that with my family. Prior to this weekend, we were using artisan snow. You know, it's the handcrafted snow where you have to really maneuver yourself carefully down the slopes. But this, now we got some powder, some soft, fluffy snow. So I have two guests today on the rostrum. And the first one is Christy Germscheid. She is the executive director of Ski New Mexico. Go ahead and stand up.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_10
segments.text: to the house. She's been with the ski industry for 28 years. She was previously the vice president of Angel Fire Resort and made the move to Ski New Mexico in 2024, where she welcomed the opportunity to advocate for the ski industry throughout the state of New Mexico. Thank you so much. And our next is John Paul Bradley, and he is the general manager at Sipapu Ski and Summer Resort. The resort started.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_10
segments.text: started at the resort in 2021 as a mountain manager, and he's been the general manager now since 2020. See Papu is proud to have commissioned the new chairlift this past weekend, which is a continuation of many of their capital improvements over the last several years with more to come. I don't know, I think I've been to the majority of the New Mexico ski resorts, but Sipapu is definitely the standard go-to if you're taking a whole bunch of kids on field trips and groups and camps. And Sipapu is a lot of fun. So I look forward to seeing those improvements. And we just are so, so appreciative of the snow. And for me, it is just another promise that we have. As long as the earth remains, there will always be seed time and harvest. There will always be summer and winter. And I'm just so. Grateful that somebody else has got this under control.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: Thank you, and welcome to your guest. Certainly, it was a blessing to have that snow this weekend. Hopefully, we get more of it. Hopefully, it remains on the mountain as snowpack so that we can have water

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: do not eat the yellow snow.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_12
segments.text: to remind my kid of that this weekend. I was like, nope, don't use that one. That's not a good snowball. It's yellow. I'm right, right?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: you, Mr. Speaker. You'll see on your desks today a big brown box. A land of enchantment awaits. And I'm happy to be the sponsor of this amazing box with all these goodies inside. Enjoy. And I want to give a big thank you. To New Mexico True, the New Mexico Tourism Department, Secretary Lansing Adams, and the entire staff for your leadership and hard work in showcasing the unique spirit of our state. Because of your efforts, New Mexico welcomed a record-setting 42.6 million visitors, generating $8.8 billion in direct visitor spending, contributing to a $12 billion total economic impact, and supporting over 95,000 jobs across our state and communities. Your dedication not only celebrates our culture and beauty, but strengthens our economy and quality of life. So if you see any of the New Mexico True, any of our tourism folks around, give them a thank you. And this is them appreciating us by giving us this well-welcome box of goodies. Enjoy it and get out and visit your ski since it's a day, ski day, get out. And go skiing, but if it skiing is not for you, there's lots of food to eat, there's lots of activities to do, and all that brings a healthy economy to our state. Thank you.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_09
segments.text: Executive Message Number 15. Speaker Martinez and members of the House, pursuant to Article 4, Section 5b2 of the New Mexico Constitution, I am authorizing for your consideration during the 57th Legislature's second session, submission of House Bill 108, a bill requiring a soil and water conservation district to levy taxes upon request of a watershed district within the soil and water conservation district's boundaries.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_09
segments.text: clarifying the procedure for appointing directors of a watershed district's board of directors. Respectfully yours, Michelle Luhan Grisham, Governor.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_09

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_09

Respectfully yours, Michelle Huangrisham, Governor.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02
segments.text: Bill 66, introduced by Representative Chandler, an act relating to health care professional loan repayment, creating the Health Professions Advisory Committee to select recipients of loan repayment awards, requiring award recipients to be health professionals who currently maintain practice in New Mexico or agree to relocate to and commence practice in New Mexico, requiring the higher education department to determine and disperse award amounts, providing powers and duties, providing additional award criteria, adding definitions, allowing fees to be assessed upon breach of contract, omitting the health professional loan repayment.
